questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient came to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain, vomiting for 4-5 hours. On PA examination abdomen was tender. His Chest radiogram and X-Ray abdominal standing were done. The chest radiogram was suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. The surgeon elects for emergency laparotomy, which is to be done under general anaesthesia. What are the neurophysiological states produced by general anaesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The neurophysiologic state produced by general anaesthetics is characterised by five primary effects: Unconsciousness, amnesia, analgesia, inhibition of autonomic reflexes, and skeletal muscle relaxation.
  • None of the currently available anaesthetic agents, when used alone, can achieve all five of these desired effects.
  • In addition, an ideal anaesthetic drug should induce rapid, smooth loss of consciousness, be rapidly reversible upon discontinuation and possess a wide margin of safety.
  • The modern practice of anaesthesiology relies on the use of combinations of intravenous and inhaled drugs (balanced anaesthesia techniques) to take advantage of the favourable properties of each agent while minimising their adverse effects.
  • The choice of anaesthetic technique is determined by the type of diagnostic, therapeutic, or surgical intervention to be performed.

questions.text:
Which of the following sentences are TRUE for inhalational anaesthetic agents?
1. More solubility of gases causes rapid induction of anaesthesia
2. Less solubility of gases causes rapid induction of anaesthesia
3. More solubility of gases causes slow induction of anaesthesia
4. Less solubility of gases causes slow induction of anaesthesia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • One of the most important factors influencing the transfer of an anaesthetic from the lungs to the arterial blood is its solubility characteristics.
  • The blood-gas partition coefficient is a useful index of solubility and defines the relative affinity of an anaesthetic for blood compared with that of the inspired gas.
  • The partition coefficients for desflurane and nitrous oxide, which are relatively insoluble in blood, are extremely low.
  • Low blood solubility anaesthetics:
    • Few molecules are needed to raise the blood partial pressure.
    • Arterial tension rises rapidly.
    • Leads to faster induction of anaesthesia.
  • Moderate to high blood solubility anaesthetics:
    • More molecules dissolve in the blood before the partial pressure rises.
    • Arterial tension increases more slowly.
    • Results in slower induction.
  • Blood: Gas Partition Coefficient:
    • Indicates how much anaesthetic dissolves in blood relative to alveolar gas.
    • Nitrous oxide has a coefficient of 47, meaning:
      • At equilibrium, its blood concentration is 0.47x the alveolar concentration.
  • Effect of higher blood: gas partition coefficient:
    • Greater uptake into the blood.
    • Slows the rate at which FA/FI (alveolar to inspired ratio) approaches 1.
    • Therefore, there is a slower onset of anaesthesia.

questions.text: Traditionally, anaesthetic effect on the brain produces four stages. Match the following four stages of anaesthesia with their effects.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Traditionally, anaesthetic effects on the brain produce four stages or levels of increasing depth of CNS depression (Guedel's signs, derived from observations of the effects of inhaled diethyl ether):
    • Stage I-analgesia:The patient initially experiences analgesia without amnesia. Later in stage I, both analgesia and amnesia are produced.
    • Stage II-excitement:During this stage, the patient appears delirious, may vocalise, but is completely amnesic. Respiration is rapid, and heart rate and blood pressure increase. Duration and severity of this light stage of anaesthesia rapidly increase with the concentration of the agent.
    • Stage III-surgical anaesthesia:This stage begins with slowing of respiration and heart rate, and extends to complete cessation of spontaneous respiration (apnea). Four planes of stage III are described based on changes in ocular movements, eye reflexes, and pupil size, indicating increasing depth of anaesthesia.
    • Stage IV-medullary depression:This deep stage of anaesthesia represents severe depression of the CNS, including the vasomotor centre in the medulla and the respiratory centre in the brainstem. Without circulatory and respiratory support, death would rapidly ensue.

questions.text:
Which of the following sentences are true for their action of halogenated inhaled anaesthetic agents?
1. They cause CNS depression
2. They depress cardiac activity
3. They cause bronchoconstriction
4. They increase GFR
5. They decrease portal vein flow
6. They relax the Uterine muscles
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Halothane, enflurane, isoflurane, desflurane, and sevoflurane all depress normal cardiac contractility (halothane and enflurane more so than isoflurane, desflurane, and sevoflurane). As a result, all volatile agents tend to decrease mean arterial pressure in direct proportion to their alveolar concentration.
  • All volatile anaesthetics possess varying degrees of bronchodilating properties, an effect of value in patients with active wheezing and in status asthmatics. However, airway irritation, which may provoke coughing or breath-holding, is induced by the pungency of some volatile anaesthetics. The pungency of isoflurane and desflurane makes these agents less suitable for the induction of anaesthesia in patients with active bronchospasm. These reactions rarely occur with halothane and sevoflurane, which are considered non-pungent.
    • Therefore, the bronchodilating action of halothane and sevoflurane makes them the agents of choice in patients with underlying airway problems. Nitrous oxide is also nonpungent and can facilitate inhalational induction of anaesthesia in a patient with bronchospasm.
  • Inhaled anaesthetics tend to decrease glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and urine flow. Renal blood flow may also be decreased by some agents, but filtration fraction is increased, implying that autoregulatory control of efferent arteriole tone helps compensate and limits the reduction in GFR.
  • Volatile anaesthetics cause a concentration-dependent decrease in portal vein blood flow that parallels the decline in cardiac output produced by these agents. However, total hepatic blood flow may be relatively preserved as hepatic artery blood flow to the liver may increase or stay the same. Although transient changes in liver function tests may occur following exposure to volatile anaesthetics, persistent elevation in liver enzymes is rare except following repeated exposures to halothane (see Toxicity of Anaesthetic Agents).
    • Nitrous oxide appears to have little effect on uterine musculature. However, the halogenated anaesthetics are potent uterine muscle relaxants and produce this effect in a concentration-dependent fashion. This pharmacologic effect can be helpful when profound uterine relaxation is required for intrauterine fetal manipulation or manual extraction of a retained placenta during delivery. However, it can also lead to increased uterine bleeding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient underwent abdominal hysterectomy under general anaesthesia with skeletal muscle relaxant Succinylcholine. Suddenly she develops Muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, rapid onset of tachycardia, hypercapnia, hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis. Which of the following drugs should be given to reduce calcium release from the Sarcoplasmic reticulum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Malignant hyperthermia is a heritable genetic disorder of skeletal muscle that occurs in susceptible individuals exposed to volatile anaesthetics while undergoing general anaesthesia.
  • The depolarising muscle relaxant succinylcholine may also trigger malignant hyperthermia.
    • The malignant hyperthermia syndrome consists of muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, rapid onset of tachycardia and hypercapnia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis following exposure to one or more triggering agents.
    • Malignant hyperthermia is a rare but important cause of anaesthetic morbidity and mortality. The specific biochemical abnormality is an increase in free cytosolic calcium concentration in skeletal muscle cells.
    • Treatment includes administration of dantrolene (to reduce calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum) and appropriate measures to reduce body temperature and restore electrolyte and acid-base balance

choices.text: Potentiation of chloride current mediated through the GABAa receptor complex
Potentiation of chloride current mediated through the GABAb receptor complex
Potentiation of Sodium current mediated through the GABAa receptor complex
Potentiation of sodium current mediated through the GABAb receptor complex

questions.text: Propofol is a widely used general anaesthetic agent. What is the presumed mechanism of action of Propofol?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Propofol (2,6-diisopropylphenol) is an alkyl phenol with hypnotic properties that is chemically distinct from other groups of intravenous anaesthetics.
  • Because of its poor solubility in water, it is formulated as an emulsion containing 10% soybean oil, 2.25% glycerol, and 1.2% lecithin, the major component of the egg yolk phosphatide fraction.
  • Hence, susceptible patients may experience allergic reactions.
  • The presence of soybean oil makes the injection painful.
  • The solution appears milky white and slightly viscous, has a pH of approximately 7, and a Propofol concentration of 1% (10 mg/mL).
  • In some countries, a 2% formulation is available.
  • Although retardants of bacterial growth are added to the formulations, solutions should be used as soon as possible (no more than 8 hours after opening the vial), and proper sterile technique is essential.
  • The addition of metabisulfite in one of the formulations has raised concern regarding its use in patients with reactive airway disease (eg, asthma) or sulfite allergies.
  • The presumed mechanism of action of Propofol is through potentiation of the chloride current mediated through the GABA A receptor complex.

choices.text: Sentence 1 and 2 both are True, and 2 is the correct reason for 1
Sentence 1 and 2 both are True, but 2 is not the correct reason for 1
Sentence 1 is True, but Sentence 2 is False

questions.text:
Which of the following is TRUE for Propofol?
1. Propofol produces the most pronounced decrease in systemic blood pressure
2. Propofol decreases both preload and afterload
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Compared with other induction drugs, Propofol produces the most pronounced decrease in systemic blood pressure; this is a result of profound vasodilation in both arterial and venous circulations, leading to reductions in preload and afterload.
  • This effect on systemic blood pressure is more pronounced with increased age, in patients with reduced intravascular fluid volume, and with rapid injection.
  • Because the hypotensive effects are further augmented by the inhibition of the normal baroreflex response, the vasodilation only leads to a small increase in heart rate.
  • Profound bradycardia and asystole after the administration of Propofol have been described in healthy adults despite prophylactic anticholinergic drugs.

choices.text: Fospropofol is a prodrug of Propofol
Propofol is a prodrug of Fospropofol

questions.text: Which of the following is False regarding propofol and fospropofol?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Injection pain during the administration of Propofol is often perceived as severe, and the lipid emulsion has several disadvantages.
  • Intense research has focused on finding alternative formulations or related drugs that would address some of these problems.
  • Fospropofol is a water-soluble prodrug of Propofol, chemically described as 2,6-diisopropylphenoxymethyl phosphate disodium salt, that was licensed by the Food and Drug Administration in 2008 as a sedating agent for use in adult patients during monitored anaesthesia care.
  • The prodrug is rapidly metabolised by alkaline phosphatase, producing Propofol, phosphate, and formaldehyde.
  • The formaldehyde is metabolised by aldehyde dehydrogenase in the liver and in erythrocytes.
  • The available fospropofol formulation is a sterile, aqueous, colourless, and clear solution that is supplied in a single-dose vial at a concentration of 35 mg/mL under the trade name Lusedra.

questions.text: Which of the following general anaesthetic agents should not be used in a patient with Acute Intermittent Porphyria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thiopental and methohexital undergo hepatic metabolism, mostly by oxidation but also by N -N-dealkylation, desulfuration, and destruction of the barbituric acid ring structure.
  • Barbiturates should not be administered to patients with acute intermittent porphyria because they increase the production of porphyrins through stimulation of aminolevulinic acid synthetase.
  • Methohexital has a shorter elimination half-time than thiopental due to its larger plasma clearance, leading to a faster and more complete recovery after bolus injection.
  • Although thiopental is metabolised more slowly and has a long elimination half-time, recovery after a single bolus injection is comparable to that of methohexital and propofol because it depends on redistribution to inactive tissue sites rather than on metabolism.
  • However, if administered through repeated bolus injections or continuous infusion, recovery will be markedly prolonged because elimination will depend on metabolism under these circumstances.

questions.text: What is the correct dose of thiopental?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The principal clinical uses of thiopental (3-5 mg/kg IV) or methohexital (1-5 mg/kg IV) is for induction of anaesthesia (unconsciousness), which usually occurs in less than 30 seconds. Patients may experience a garlic or onion taste after administration.
  • Barbiturates such as methohexital (20-30 mg/kg) may be administered per rectum to facilitate induction of anaesthesia in mentally challenged and uncooperative paediatric patients. When a barbiturate is administered with the goal of neuroprotection, an isoelectric EEG indicating maximal reduction of CMR O 2 has traditionally been used as the end point.

questions.text: Benzodiazepines are usually used as premedication before general anaesthesia. Which are the desired effect of benzodiazepines useful in premedication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Benzodiazepines commonly used in the perioperative period include midazolam, lorazepam, and less frequently, diazepam.
  • Benzodiazepines are unique among the group of intravenous anaesthetics in that their action can readily be terminated by administration of their selective antagonist, flumazenil. Their most desired effects are anxiolysis and anterograde amnesia, which are extremely useful for premedication.

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous general anaesthetic agents has cardiovascular stability?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A characteristic and desired feature of induction of anaesthesia with etomidate is cardiovascular stability after bolus injection.
  • Systemic effects of etomidate:
    • Cardiovascular Effects:
      • Minimal effect on the cardiovascular system
      • Mild decrease in peripheral vascular resistance → slight drop in blood pressure
      • Myocardial contractility and cardiac output remain stable
      • Does not cause histamine release
      • May lead to increased heart rate and blood pressure during laryngoscopy if used alone
    • Respiratory Effects:
      • Ventilation generally preserved
      • Apnea is unlikely unless combined with opioids
      • Slight increase in arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO₂)
    • Central Nervous System Effects:
      • Decreases cerebral metabolic rate, cerebral blood flow, and intracranial pressure
      • Cerebral perfusion pressure remains well-maintained
      • Increases somatosensory evoked potentials (beneficial for ECT)
      • No analgesic effect
      • Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is more frequent than with propofol or barbiturates, but similar to general anaesthesia rates
  • Side effects of etomidate:
    • Adrenocortical suppression
    • Pain on injection
    • Myoclonus (muscle jerks)
    • Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)

choices.text: It is known as dissociative anaesthesia
It differs from other agents in that it produces significant analgesia
Major effect is produced through the inhibition of the NMDA receptor complex

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE for ketamine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ketamine is a partially water-soluble and highly lipid-soluble phencyclidine derivative differing from most other intravenous anaesthetics in that it produces significant analgesia.
  • The characteristic state observed after an induction dose of ketamine is known as "dissociative anaesthesia," wherein the patient's eyes remain open with a slow nystagmic gaze (cataleptic state).
  • Of the two stereoisomers, the (+) form is more potent than the R (-) isomer, but only the racemic mixture of ketamine is available in the USA.
  • Ketamine's mechanism of action is complex, but the major effect is probably produced through inhibition of the NMDA receptor complex.

questions.text: Which is the drug that increases systemic blood pressure, but is a myocardial depressant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ketamine can produce transient but significant increases in systemic blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output, presumably by centrally mediated sympathetic stimulation.
  • These effects, which are associated with increased cardiac workload and myocardial oxygen consumption, are not always desirable and can be blunted by co-administration of benzodiazepines, opioids, or inhaled anaesthetics.
  • Though the effect is more controversial, ketamine is considered to be a direct myocardial depressant.
  • This property is usually masked by its stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system, but may become apparent in critically ill patients with limited ability to increase their sympathetic nervous system activity.
  • Ketamine can be used in shock as it stimulates the sympathetic nervous system and uncontrolled asthmatics whereas propofol is used in controlled asthmatics.

questions.text: Which drug can provide analgesia without respiratory depression
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dexmedetomidine is principally used for the short-term sedation of intubated and ventilated patients in an ICU setting. In the operating room, dexmedetomidine may be used as an adjunct to general anaesthesia or to provide sedation, eg, during awake fibre optic tracheal intubation or regional anaesthesia.
  • When administered during general anaesthesia, dexmedetomidine decreases the dose requirements for inhaled and injected anaesthetics.
  • Awakening and the transition to the postoperative setting may benefit from dexmedetomidine-produced sedative and analgesic effects without respiratory depression.

choices.text: Blockade of voltage gated sodium channels
Blockade of voltage gated Calcium channels
Blockade of voltage gated potassium channels

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male alcoholic patient came to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and weakness. His laboratory investigation and USG were performed. Laboratory investigations are
Hb- 14gm%
Platelets- 1,25,000/cu mm
SGPT- 100U/L
SGOT- 600 U/L
His USG report was suggestive of multiple hepatic liquefied abscesses. So, the surgeon is planning for pigtail catheterisation under local anaesthesia. What is the primary mechanism of action of local anaesthetics?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The primary mechanism of action of local anaesthetics is blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels.
  • The excitable membranes of nerve axons, cardiac muscle, and neuronal cell bodies maintain a resting membrane potential between -90 to -60 mV.
  • During excitation, voltage-gated sodium channels open, allowing a fast inward sodium current, which depolarizes the membrane toward +40 mV (sodium equilibrium potential).
  • This depolarization leads to inactivation of sodium channels and the opening of potassium channels.
  • The outward flow of potassium repolarizes the membrane toward the potassium equilibrium potential (approximately -95 mV).
  • Repolarization resets the sodium channels to their resting state, with a recovery time that determines the refractory period.
  • Transmembrane ionic gradients are maintained by the sodium-potassium pump (Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase).
  • These ionic fluxes are similar to those in cardiac muscle, though simpler, and local anaesthetics affect both tissues in a similar manner.

questions.text:
Which of the following sentences are TRUE regarding the added effects of vasoconstrictors?
1. Localised neuronal uptake is enhanced?
2. Gives short-duration blocks?
3. Peak blood level is increased?
4. Peak blood level is lowered?
5. Epinephrine exerts an analgesic effect during spinal anaesthesia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Adding a vasoconstrictor to a local anaesthetic increases local tissue concentration, enhancing neuronal uptake and resulting in a longer duration of block.
  • This prolonged effect can provide adequate anaesthesia for longer procedures, extend postoperative pain control, and reduce the total dose of anaesthetic required.
  • Vasoconstrictors help lower peak blood levels of the anaesthetic by slowing absorption, allowing better alignment with metabolism and elimination, which reduces systemic toxicity risk.
  • In spinal anaesthesia, epinephrine not only prolongs anaesthetic effect through vasoconstriction but may also produce a direct analgesic effect via activation of postsynaptic α2-adrenoceptors in the spinal cord.
  • This property of α2-mediated analgesia has led to the clinical use of clonidine, an α2-agonist, as an adjuvant in spinal anaesthesia.
  • However, epinephrine may increase the neurotoxicity of local anaesthetics when used in peripheral nerve blocks or spinal anaesthesia.
  • The use of vasoconstrictors in areas with limited collateral circulation (e.g., fingers, toes) is generally avoided to prevent ischemic complications, although this caution is sometimes debated in current practice.

choices.text: Early symptoms are circumoral and tongue numbness and metallic taste
At higher concentration,s nystagmus and muscular twitching occur

questions.text: Which of the following sentences is TRUE for CNS toxicity of local anaesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All local anaesthetics can cause sedation, light-headedness, visual and auditory disturbances, and restlessness when high plasma concentrations occur due to rapid absorption or accidental intravascular injection.
  • Early symptoms of local anaesthetic toxicity include numbness of the tongue and around the mouth, as well as a metallic taste.
  • At higher plasma levels, patients may develop nystagmus and muscular twitching, which can progress to tonic-clonic seizures.
  • These effects are believed to result from depression of cortical inhibitory pathways, leading to unopposed excitatory activity in the brain.
  • This excitatory phase (often seen as seizure activity) is typically followed by generalised CNS depression.
  • The classic pattern of toxicity has been mostly observed in controlled human studies (with low doses) and animal models using graded dosing.
  • In actual clinical settings, deviations from the classic toxicity pattern are common and depend on factors like:
    • Patient susceptibility
    • Type of local anaesthetic
    • Concurrent medications
    • Speed of serum drug level increase
  • A review of clinical cases of local anaesthetic-induced cardiac toxicity found that only 18% of patients showed early CNS warning signs before cardiovascular collapse.

choices.text: Sentence 1 and 2 both are True and 2 is correct reason for 1
Sentence 1 and 2 both are True but 2 is not the correct reason for 1
Sentence 1 is True but Sentence 2 is False

questions.text:
Local anaesthetic agents cause neural toxicity. Which of the following is TRUE?
1. Neural injury occurs from voltage gated sodium channels
2. Clinical effect and toxicity is tightly linked.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • It is not clear what role these factors or others play in clinical injury.
  • It is clear, however, that injury does not result from blockade of the voltage-gated sodium channel per se, and thus clinical effect and toxicity are not tightly linked.

questions.text: Which is the FALSE sentence regarding Articaine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Articaine has a shorter plasma half-life of approximately 20 minutes.

  • Articaine was approved for use as a dental anaesthetic in the USA in April 2000.
  • It is unique among amino-amide anaesthetics because it contains a thiophene ring instead of a benzene ring.
  • Articaine also includes an ester group, which allows for metabolism by plasma esterases.
  • The thiophene ring increases lipophilicity, enhancing tissue penetration. (Option A & B)
  • The ester group shortens the plasma half-life to approximately 20 minutes, potentially improving the therapeutic index and reducing systemic toxicity. (Option D)
  • Due to these properties, articaine has become widely used in dental anaesthesia, often considered more effective and possibly safer than lidocaine, the previous standard.
  • However, there are concerns about a higher risk of persistent paraesthesia with articaine, though this complication remains rare.
  • Prilocaine has been reported to have an even higher relative risk of causing paraesthesia, twice that of articaine.

choices.text: Sentences 1 and 2 both are True, and 2 is the correct reason for 1
Sentences 1 and 2 both are True, but 2 is not the correct reason for 1
Sentence 1 is True, but Sentence 2 is False

questions.text:
1. Bupivacaine is avoided when high volumes or concentrations are needed
2. It is a cardiotoxic drug and can cause cardiac arrest
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Due to cardiotoxicity concerns, bupivacaine is often avoided in procedures requiring large volumes of concentrated anaesthetic, such as epidural or peripheral nerve blocks for surgical anaesthesia.
  • Low concentrations (≤ 0.25%) of bupivacaine are commonly used to provide prolonged peripheral anaesthesia and postoperative analgesia.
  • Bupivacaine is widely used for anaesthetic infiltration to manage incisional pain after surgery.
  • It is a preferred agent for epidural infusions in postoperative pain management and labour analgesia.
  • Bupivacaine has a favourable safety profile as a spinal anaesthetic, with a low risk of neurotoxicity and minimal risk of transient neurologic symptoms (TNS).
  • However, its long duration of action makes it less suitable for outpatient or ambulatory surgery, as it may delay recovery and discharge.

choices.text: Has a longer duration of action

questions.text: Levobupivacaine is ___________ compared to bupivacaine.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Levobupivacaine is the S(-) enantiomer of bupivacaine and is considered less cardiotoxic than the racemic mixture.
  • It is slightly less potent and may have a longer duration of action, though these differences are not clinically significant.
  • Recent studies on lipid resuscitation indicate a potential advantage of levobupivacaine over ropivacaine.
  • Levobupivacaine is more effectively sequestered into a lipid sink, suggesting a greater potential for reversing toxicity if it occurs.

questions.text: Which is the reference local anaesthetic agent against which all agents are compared?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Aside from the issue of a high incidence of TNS with spinal administration, lidocaine has had an excellent record as an intermediate-duration anaesthetic, and remains the reference standard against which most anaesthetics are compared.

choices.text: Its low cardiac toxicity has led to use for high-volume peripheral blocks
Its high cardiac toxicity has led to decreased use for high-volume peripheral blocks
It is not used for epidural infusions for the control of labour

questions.text: Which is TRUE for Ropivacaine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Due to its lower cardiotoxicity, ropivacaine is widely used for high-volume peripheral nerve blocks.

  • Ropivacaine is the S(-) enantiomer in a homologous series that includes bupivacaine and mepivacaine.
  • It is characterised by its chirality and the presence of a propyl group on the piperidine ring.
  • It is also a common choice for epidural infusions in labour analgesia and postoperative pain control. (Option C)
  • Some studies suggest that ropivacaine may offer a more favourable differential block compared to bupivacaine.
  • However, its lower clinical potency complicates direct comparisons with bupivacaine.

questions.text: Which skeletal muscle relaxant follows Hoffman elimination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atracurium is an intermediate-acting, nondepolarizing muscle relaxant of the isoquinoline class.
  • It is metabolised by both the liver and Hofmann elimination, a form of spontaneous nonenzymatic breakdown.
  • The primary breakdown products are laudanosine and a quaternary acid, neither of which has neuromuscular blocking activity.
  • Laudanosine is slowly metabolised by the liver and has a relatively long elimination half-life of about 150 minutes.
  • It can cross the blood-brain barrier, and high concentrations may cause seizures and increase the requirement for volatile anaesthetics.
  • During routine surgical anaesthesia, laudanosine blood levels typically range from 2 to 1 mcg/mL.
  • With prolonged atracurium infusions in the ICU, laudanosine levels may exceed 5 mcg/mL, raising the risk of CNS toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a nondepolarizing relaxant agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Succinylcholine is a depolarising muscle relaxant.

Depolarising Relaxant Drugs:

  • Succinylcholine is a depolarising muscle relaxant with a very short duration of action (5-10 minutes).
  • Its rapid breakdown is due to hydrolysis by butyrylcholinesterase in the liver and pseudocholinesterase in the plasma.
  • Plasma cholinesterase metabolism is the main elimination pathway for succinylcholine.
  • Succinylcholine is metabolised faster than mivacurium, resulting in a shorter duration of action.
  • Its primary metabolite, succinylmonocholine, is further broken down into succinic acid and choline.
  • Only a small fraction of the administered dose reaches the neuromuscular junction, due to the high hydrolytic capacity of plasma cholinesterase.
  • Since there is minimal or no plasma cholinesterase at the motor end plate, the blockade ends as the drug diffuses away into the extracellular fluid.
  • The circulating levels of plasma cholinesterase influence the duration of succinylcholine action by regulating how much drug reaches the motor end plate.

choices.text: Mechanism of action is through depolarising and desensitising

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE for depolarising agents?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Depolarising Relaxant Drugs

  • The very short duration of action of succinylcholine (5-10 minutes) is due to its rapid hydrolysis by butyrylcholinesterase in the liver and pseudocholinesterase in the plasma.
  • Plasma cholinesterase metabolism is the primary route of succinylcholine elimination.
  • Because succinylcholine is metabolised faster than mivacurium, it has a shorter duration of action.
  • The main metabolite, succinylmonocholine, is quickly broken down into succinic acid and choline.
  • Due to the high hydrolytic capacity of plasma cholinesterase, only a small fraction of the intravenous dose reaches the neuromuscular junction.
  • There is little or no plasma cholinesterase at the motor end plate, so blockade ends by diffusion of succinylcholine away from the end plate into the extracellular fluid.
  • The duration of action of succinylcholine is influenced by circulating plasma cholinesterase levels, which determine how much drug reaches the motor end plate.

questions.text:
The adverse effects of depolarising agents are
1. Hyperkalemia
2. Hypokalemia
3. Increased intraocular pressure
4. Decreased intraocular pressure
5. Increased intragastric pressure
6. Muscle pain
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The adverse effects of depolarising agents are hyperkalemia, raised intraocular pressure, increased intragastric pressure, and myalgias.

  • Hyperkalemia:
    • Patients with burns, nerve damage, neuromuscular diseases, closed head injury, or other trauma may experience potassium release into the bloodstream after succinylcholine administration.
    • This potassium surge can, in rare cases, lead to cardiac arrest.
  • Increased Intraocular Pressure:
    • Succinylcholine administration can cause a rapid rise in intraocular pressure within 60 seconds, peaking at 2-4 minutes, and subsiding after 5 minutes.
    • The mechanism may involve tonic myofibril contraction or transient dilation of choroidal vessels.
    • Although intraocular pressure increases, succinylcholine is not contraindicated for eye surgery unless the anterior chamber is open (e.g., open globe injury).
  • Increased Intragastric Pressure:
    • In heavily muscled patients, succinylcholine-induced fasciculations can raise intragastric pressure by 5 to 40 cm H₂O.
    • This raises the risk of regurgitation and aspiration, especially in patients with delayed gastric emptying (e.g., diabetes), emergency trauma cases, oesophageal dysfunction, or morbid obesity.
  • Muscle Pain (Myalgias):
    • Postoperative myalgias are common in heavily muscled individuals and those receiving higher doses of succinylcholine (> 1.5 mg/kg).

choices.text: Activation of GABAb receptors resulting in depolarisation
Activation of GABAb receptors resulting in repolarisation
Activation of GABAb receptors resulting in hyperpolarisation

questions.text: Baclofen acts by...
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Baclofen ( p -p-chlorophenyl-GABA) was designed to be an orally active GABA-mimetic agent and is an agonist at GABA B receptors.
  • Activation of these receptors by baclofen results in hyperpolarisation, probably by increased K+ + conductance
